Rainfall erosivity is the potential of rainfall to cause soil erosion by raindrop impact and surface wash out when infiltration capacity is exceeded. It is commonly represented by the R-factor in soil erosion prediction models such as Universal Soil Loss Equation (USLE)
10 and it revised version (RUSLE)
11 . As rainfall is the driving force of water erosion, the rainfall erosivity is an important factor in the USLE and its revised versions
12 . It is a crucial parameter for soil erosion risk assessment that considers different future land use and climate change scenarios
13 , and for proposing conservation practices
14 . The R-factor is also an important parameter for assessing the risk of soil erosion under global warming conditions because it is highly influenced by a changing climate
13, 15, 16 .
